original_data.question: A 60-year-old man with severe persistent asthma since the age of 14 presents with an acute exacerbation of shortness of breath, wheezing, and coughing over the last several days. His asthmatic symptoms are usually well controlled with regular high-dose inhaled triamcinolone, but over the last week or so he has developed a nocturnal cough and mild wheezing despite good compliance with controller medications. A review of several spirometry reports suggest of bronchial asthma with a partial irreversible airway obstruction. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with the recent loss of asthma control in this patient?

model_response:
The correct answer is C (Airway remodeling). Loss of asthma control in a patient with long-standing asthma is often associated with the development of airway remodeling. Airway remodeling is characterized by an increase in the size of the airway smooth muscle, an increase in the size of the submucosal glands, and an increase in the thickness of the epithelial reticular basement membrane. Airway remodeling is associated with an increased risk of death and a blunted response to bronchodilators. Airway epithelial shedding (choice A) is not associated with loss of asthma control. Diagnosis: Asthma

### COMMENTS: This question is a bit unusual in that the correct answer is not one of the choices. The correct answer is airway remodeling. The other choices are features of airway remodeling. Airway epithelial shedding is a feature of airway remodeling. Airway smooth muscle atrophy is not a feature of airway remodeling. Airway smooth muscle hypertrophy and hyperplasia are features of airway remodeling. Airway remodeling is associated with an increased risk of death and a blunted response to bronchodilators.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
Retained; never-ceasing.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
Height greater than two standard deviations below the mean of the appropriate reference population for the age and sex of the individual.

A symptom and a finding during physical examination, characterized by a high-pitched, whistling sound during breathing. It results from the narrowing or obstruction of the respiratory airways. The most common causes of wheezing are asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, tracheobronchitis, and pulmonary edema.

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.

Persistent health symptoms which remain unexplained after a complete medical evaluation. A cluster of symptoms that consistently appear together but without a known cause are referred to as a MEDICALLY UNEXPLAINED SYNDROME (MUS).
The act of directing or determining; regulation or maintenance of a function or action; a relation of constraint of one entity (thing or person or group) by another.

A regimen consisting of high-dose (HD) methotrexate (MTX) plus HD cytarabine (AraC) that can be used in the treatment of central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma and refractory or relapsed (RR) non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).

A glucocorticoid given, as the free alcohol or in esterified form, orally, intramuscularly, by local injection, by inhalation, or applied topically in the management of various disorders in which corticosteroids are indicated. (From Martindale, The Extra Pharmacopoeia, 30th ed, p739)
Any period of seven consecutive days.

A symptom and a finding during physical examination, characterized by a high-pitched, whistling sound during breathing. It results from the narrowing or obstruction of the respiratory airways. The most common causes of wheezing are asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, tracheobronchitis, and pulmonary edema.
Distensibility measure of a chamber such as the lungs (LUNG COMPLIANCE) or bladder. Compliance is expressed as a change in volume per unit change in pressure.
A device designed to control or regulate the operation of another device.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.

An article or book published after examination of published material on a subject. It may be comprehensive to various degrees and the time range of material scrutinized may be broad or narrow, but the reviews most often desired are reviews of the current literature. The textual material examined may be equally broad and can encompass, in medicine specifically, clinical material as well as experimental research or case reports. State-of-the-art reviews tend to address more current matters. A review of the literature must be differentiated from HISTORICAL ARTICLE on the same subject, but a review of historical literature is also within the scope of this publication type.
Measurement of volume of air inhaled or exhaled by the lung.

A form of bronchial disorder with three distinct components: airway hyper-responsiveness (RESPIRATORY HYPERSENSITIVITY), airway INFLAMMATION, and intermittent AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION. It is characterized by spasmodic contraction of airway smooth muscle, WHEEZING, and dyspnea (DYSPNEA, PAROXYSMAL).
Being or affecting only a part of something.
A class of substances that irreversibly and permanently binds to and decreases the activity of, and/or deactivates a target.
Any hindrance to the passage of air into and out of the lungs.
Joined in some kind of relationship.

A form of bronchial disorder with three distinct components: airway hyper-responsiveness (RESPIRATORY HYPERSENSITIVITY), airway INFLAMMATION, and intermittent AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION. It is characterized by spasmodic contraction of airway smooth muscle, WHEEZING, and dyspnea (DYSPNEA, PAROXYSMAL).
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
